article:
'Amatoritsero Ede' is a Nigerian-Canadian poet. In 1998 he won the All-Africa
Christopher Okigbo Prize for Literature with his first collection of poems,
Caribbean Blues; A writer's Pains. He had written under the name "Godwin Ede".
He stopped bearing his 'Christian' first name as a way to protest the xenophobia
and racism he noted in Germany, a 'Christian' country, and to an extent, to
protest Western colonialism in
general. [http://www.sentinelpoetry.org.uk/magazine0304/page16.html Sentinel
Poetry] He was a Hindu Monk with the Hare Krishna Movement, and has worked
as a Book Editor with a major Nigerian trade publisher, Spectrum Books. In 1993
he won the runner-up prize of the Association of Nigerian Authorsâ (ANA) Poetry
Competition with the manuscript of âA Writerâs Painsâ; in 1998 the ANA All
Africa Christopher Okigbo Prize for Literature (endowed by Wole Soyinka,
Nigerian Nobel Laureate for literature) with his first collection of poems,
Collected Poems: A writerâs Pains & Caribbean Blues (Bremen, Germany: Yeti
Press, 1998; Lagos: Oracle Books, 2001) and second prize in the first May Ayim
Award: International Black German Literary Prize, in 2004. He also appears in
the following anthologies: TOK 1: Writing the New Toronto Helen Walsh ed.
(Toronto: Zephyr Press, 2006), Camouflage: Best of Contemporary Nigerian Writing
Nduka Otiono & Diego Okonyedo eds. (Yenogoa, Nigeria: Treasure Books, 2006), May
Ayim Award Anthology Peggy Piesche et al. eds. (Berlin, Germany: Orlanda Verlag,
2004), The Fate of Vultures: BBC Prize-Winning Poetry. Peter Porter et al. eds.
(Oxford: Heinemann International, 1989), Und auf den Strassen eine Pest Uche
Nduka ed. (Bad Honnef, Germany: Horlemann Verlag, 1996) and Voices from the
Fringe: An ANA Anthology of New Nigerian Poetry. Harry Garuba ed. (Lagos:
Malthouse Press, 1988). His second Collection, Globetrotter & Hitlerâs Children
(New York: Akaschic Books, 2009), is out. He was the 2005-2006 Writer-in-
Residence at Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada under the auspices of PEN
Canadaâs Writer-in-Exile network. He edited Sentinel Online poetry journal from
2005 to 2007. He is a SSHRC Fellow and Doctoral Candidate in English literature
at Carleton University, Ottawa. He is the Publisher and Managing Editor of Maple
Tree Literary Supplement, MTLS at . Ede has lived in Canada since
2002, sponsored as a writer-in-exile by PEN Canada. Between 2005 and 2007 he
edited an international online poetry journal, Sentinel Poetry Online. [http://www.pencanada.ca/programs/exile/cat-
Nigeria.php Writers in Exile (Nigeria), PEN Canada] [http://www.now.carleton.ca/2005-
12/1026.htm Carleton hosts writer-in-exile, Carleton University]
